question: Which system component is responsible for converting raw symptoms into a disease probability vector?
What is the role of the “Specialist-Classifier”?
options: To convert probability values into specialist labels
To recommend specialists based on all predicted diseases.
To recommend specialists based on top 3 predicted diseases.
To recommend any specialists at random.

question: T/F: The LLM provides its own independent disease diagnosis.
T/F: The LLM module “re-scores” the diseases using its internal weights.
Why does our system show the top 3 most likely diseases instead of the single most likely disease?
options: Because classifier models can only output three values.
To give users alternative hypotheses when the first choice might be ambiguous.
Because the specialist classifier cannot work with only one disease.

question: What happens in the system after the top 3 diseases are picked?
options: Specialist Classifier takes the disease labels and their probability values to recommend specialists.
Specialist Classifier takes the disease labels only to recommend specialists.
LLM (AI Chatbot) generates explanation for predicted diseases and recommends specialists.

question: What input/s does the Specialist-Classifier require?
Which of the following are the roles of LLM integration?
options: Translate models predictions into user-friendly language
Fine-tune the disease classifier on the user’s data.
Answer the follow-up questions about why a particular disease or specialist was chosen.

question: Which component in our system first converts the user’s listed symptoms into a candidate disease ranking?
After the Disease Classifier predicts the top three outputs, the next step is to feed the disease labels into the:
Why does the system ask the users to choose from pre-defined symptom options, rather than letting them type 'free-text' descriptions?
options: Because it speeds up LLM inference.
Because the Disease Classifier was trained only on structured symptom features.
To ensure the Specialist Classifier runs correctly.

question:
Which three diseases will the user see as the ‘top 3’?

Gastroenteritis: 0.32
Heart attack: 0.28
Hepatitis D: 0.15
Jaundice: 0.12
Others: 0.13
If Disease A has a probability of 0.35, Disease B 0.32, Disease C 0.10, Disease D 0.18 and others <0.05, which three will be shown by the system?
options: Disease A, Disease B, Disease C
Disease B, Disease C, Disease D
Disease D, Disease A, Disease B

question:
Which specialist does the system recommend?

Gastroenterologist: 0.45
Cardiologist: 0.25
General Physician: 0.20
Others: 0.10
options: No recommendation because the highest probability is less than 0.5

question:
After seeing Gastroenteritis (0.32, 32%) as the top disease, the user asks the LLM: 
'Why did the model favor Gastroenteritis over heart attack?' The LLM might respond 'Because your lab values of elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and recent history of diarrhea were the strongest factors in the random forest, giving Gastroenteritis a 32% score versus 28% for Heart attack.'
.Which of the following follow-up questions could reveal a potential flaw?
options: Did the model actually use CRP levels as an input feature?
Could diarrhea be caused by something other than Gastroenteritis?
At what probability would Heart attack become the top prediction?

question: If a patient's true condition is Jaundice (unknown to the model), but Jaundice only scores 0.12, lower than Hepatitis D (0.15), and Jaundice does not appear in the top 3, what might this suggest about the classifier's confusion?
options: The model grouped Jaundice and Hepatitis D under the same label.
The model was biased to rank liver conditions higher.
The Specialist Classifier overruled the Disease Classifier.
The model may be mistaking Jaundice symptoms as evidence for Hepatitis D.

question:
Given the same patient's data, the system shows: 
Gastroenteritis	: 0.32
Heart attack	: 0.28 
Hepatitis D	: 0.15 
Jaundice	: 0.12 
Others	: 0.13 
Why might the LLM explanation still emphasize Heart attack, even if Gastroenteritis has the highest probability?
options: Because the LLM always ignores the top prediction.
Because the model doesn’t trust its prediction for Gastroenteritis.
Because Heart attack was mentioned in a previous patient record.
Because Heart attack is clinically more urgent and flagged for priority in explanations.
